{"title":"Page 23","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"HEROIC WOMEN OF THE SOUTH;
MADAME ANN D. W. SPLANE.
These sketches which have for so many years been hidden
within the leaves of my diary have, some of them, been transferred to the I .trior Magazine", and, as they were received with
thought fit to continue them.
There are very many women of the South who have braved
chivalrous deeds deserve a high place in the standard of fame.
These have lived and died, in a pioneer country, unhonored and
unsung, and from the oral traditions of family lore, I have collected much of tho history of several characters.
The lady whose name heads this article was born in Richmond
county, Georgia, and educated in the city of Augusta. Her
maiden name was Douglas, and she is connected with a numerous
and respectable family in that State.
About tho year of 1820, she was married to Judge Wilkerson,
of Scriven county, who was a gentleman of high social excellence,
and popttl i 1 vi esj 11 ibly related
idy spent many years of her
married life in uninterrupted happiness in her native State.
But her time of trouble came, and her first trial tested her
courage, by the death of her husband, who died without making
0 p vi ion whatever for her destitute widowhood, leaving his
